broad.question: You have been assigned to study a group of ancient coins from the Allard Pierson collection to understand their historical significance. What is your first step in starting this research?
tiny_learn: Material culture includes physical objects created and used by past societies that help us learn about history.
Begin research by exploring both the archaeological objects and relevant scholarly literature in the university library.
This is what you will learn in the course "Objects in Context. An Interdisciplinary Perspective on the Ancient World" taught by prof. S. Srinivasan.

A.text: Visit the archaeological collection to closely examine the coins' physical characteristics and inscriptions firsthand.

B.text: Search academic databases for articles and sources about ancient coins and their historical context.

C.text: Create a detailed drawing or artistic representation of the coins to visualize their design and symbols.

D.text: Discuss with classmates to share preliminary observations and hypotheses on what the coins might reflect historically.

E.text: Develop a plan outlining the research questions and objectives guiding your study of the coins.

F.text: Organize your references and set up a bibliography framework for tracking sources you will use in your writing.

broad.question: You have just started the course and need to pick a classical canonical item not covered in class for your group research project. What is your first step?
tiny_learn: A classical canon is a set of culturally significant texts, places, or monuments considered essential heritage.
Begin your research by identifying unique items not yet discussed in lectures to ensure originality.
This course 'The Classical Canon I: The Heritage of Antiquity' taught by prof. K.N.M Mwandingi explores key canonical works and their historical meanings.

A.text: Visit a museum to observe and sketch classical artifacts for inspiration on your project.

B.text: Read scholarly articles on lesser-known classical texts to find a suitable research topic.

C.text: Create a creative narrative imagining the life surrounding a chosen classical monument.

D.text: Organize a study group to discuss potential topics and share ideas with classmates.

E.text: Contact local cultural institutions to explore collaborative research opportunities.

F.text: Outline a detailed project plan listing sources, timelines, and presentation goals.

R.question: You have been assigned to research an ancient coin from the Allard Pierson collection. What is your first step to understand its historical context?
tiny_learn: Material culture refers to physical objects used by past societies that can reveal historical information.
Start research by locating relevant academic sources and primary materials in the university library.

In the course "Objects in Context. An Interdisciplinary Perspective on the Ancient World" taught by prof. S. Srinivasan, you learn to evaluate objects as historical sources and combine written and material evidence.

A.text: Begin by sketching the coin’s design to interpret its symbolism and artistic style.

B.text: Search the university library catalogue for scholarly articles and primary sources about ancient coins.

C.text: Discuss with peers how the coin might have been used in religious or domestic contexts in antiquity.

R.question: You just received your assignment to analyze an ancient statue from the Allard Pierson collection. What should be your first step in working with this object?
tiny_learn: Material culture refers to physical objects created and used by past societies that provide clues about their lives.
Start by conducting a detailed observation of the object and consulting both primary and scholarly sources for context.
This course 'Objects in Context. An Interdisciplinary Perspective on the Ancient World' taught by prof. S. Srinivasan helps you learn to evaluate objects as historical sources.

A.text: Research existing academic articles that discuss similar statues and their historical context.

B.text: Investigate the physical features and craftsmanship of the statue to hypothesize its use and meaning.

C.text: Speak with your classmates or professor to exchange ideas about possible interpretations of the statue.

R.question: You have just received a detailed description of an ancient statue from the archaeological collection. What should be your first step to start your research on this object?
tiny_learn: Material culture refers to physical objects created and used by people in the past that help us understand history.
Start your research by identifying and categorizing the type of object before looking for academic sources.
In "Objects in Context", taught by prof. S. Srinivasan, you will learn to evaluate and research ancient objects through academic methods.

A.text: Begin drafting an academic text describing the statue's features and possible historical context.

B.text: Visit the university library to find scholarship and primary sources about similar statues for background information.

C.text: Classify the statue as a religious, domestic, or funerary object to understand its use and origin.

R.question: You need to prepare your first group presentation on a canonical item not discussed in class. What is your initial step?
tiny_learn: A canonical item is a work, place, or artifact recognized as representative of cultural heritage over time.
Start by choosing a topic that interests the group and conduct preliminary research on its historical and cultural context.

In the course "The Classical Canon I: The Heritage of Antiquity" taught by prof. K.N.M Mwandingi, you will learn to analyze and present classical heritage items through historical, literary, and archaeological perspectives.

A.text: Draft an outline focusing on the historical significance and cultural impact of your chosen canonical item.

B.text: Begin collecting and interpreting relevant ancient texts and archaeological findings about the item.

C.text: Plan how to collaborate with your group members to design an engaging seminar presentation.

R.question: You have just started 'The Classical Canon I' course and need to prepare for your group presentation. What should you do first?
tiny_learn: The classical canon consists of key texts and monuments from antiquity that have shaped cultural heritage.
Start by identifying a canonical item not discussed in class for your research project with your group.
In this course taught by prof. K.N.M Mwandingi, you'll analyze famous classical works and present your findings.

A.text: Research a canonical text or monument to understand its historical context and significance.

B.text: Investigate how to organize your findings and prepare an engaging oral presentation.

C.text: Schedule a group meeting to brainstorm possible case studies and assign research tasks.

R.question: You have been asked to contribute to a group presentation on a classical monument's historical significance. What should you do first?
tiny_learn: The classical canon includes important texts and monuments from ancient times that shaped cultural memory.
Gathering historical and archaeological information helps build a solid foundation for research.
In the course "The Classical Canon I: The Heritage of Antiquity" taught by prof. K.N.M Mwandingi, you learn to analyze canonical works and their contexts.

A.text: Research the historical background of the monument to understand its significance.

B.text: Engage your creativity to design a visually appealing presentation layout for the group.

C.text: Coordinate with your group members to divide tasks and set deadlines.

aptitude.question: Sort these ancient objects according to whether they primarily belong to the sacred, domestic, or funerary context.
tiny_learn: Ancient objects can be grouped by the role they played in daily life or rituals.
Understanding the context of an object helps us learn about the people who used it.
Objects from sacred, domestic, or funerary contexts often tell different historical stories.

items.text: Bronze statue of a deity
Clay cooking pot
Funerary urn with ashes
Stone relief from a temple wall
Wooden chair used in a household
Gold burial mask

aptitude.hint: Think about where and why these objects were used in ancient times.
aptitude.course_name: Objects in Context. An Interdisciplinary Perspective on the Ancient World

aptitude.question: Complete the text
tiny_learn: Material objects like statues and coins help us learn about ancient people's lives.
Objects must be studied in their historical context to understand their meaning.
Comparing objects with written texts can reveal different perspectives on the past.
aptitude.textWithBlanks: In Ancient Studies, an object such as a {{0}} can tell us about trade and economy, while a {{1}} found in a tomb might reveal beliefs about the {{2}}.
aptitude.hint: Think about objects linked to economy, funerary customs, and beliefs.
aptitude.course_name: Objects in Context. An Interdisciplinary Perspective on the Ancient World

aptitude.question: Looking at the graph showing the number of different types of ancient objects found in the Allard Pierson collection, which category appears most frequently?
tiny_learn: Material objects like statues and coins help us understand ancient people's daily lives and beliefs.
Different object types give different kinds of historical information depending on their use and context.
Counting objects in categories helps researchers identify what was important in ancient societies.

graphData.title: Number of Ancient Objects by Category

aptitude.hint: Look for the tallest bar representing the largest quantity.
aptitude.course_name: Objects in Context. An Interdisciplinary Perspective on the Ancient World

aptitude.question: Sort these classical works and monuments into 'Literary Works' or 'Historical/Archaeological Monuments'.
tiny_learn: The classical canon includes both texts and physical monuments from ancient times.
Literary works are texts like epics and plays, while monuments are physical structures or sites.
Understanding the difference helps you see how culture was preserved in different ways.

items.text: The Gilgamesh Epic
The Athenian Akropolis
Virgil's Aeneid
The Ara Pacis
Homer's Iliad
The Battle of Thermopylai (site and historical event)

aptitude.hint: Think about whether the item is a text to read or a place/structure to visit.
aptitude.course_name: The Classical Canon I: The Heritage of Antiquity

aptitude.question: Complete the text by choosing the correct words.
tiny_learn: The Classical Canon includes important works from literature, history, and art.
Some key places like the Athenian Akropolis symbolize ancient cultural memory.
The Battle of Thermopylai is a famous event that shaped later historical narratives.
aptitude.textWithBlanks: The {{0}} is a famous ancient Greek poet known for epic poems like the {{1}} and the Odyssey. The {{2}} was a significant battle where Greek forces, including Spartans, fought against the Persian army.
aptitude.hint: Think about the most famous Greek epic poet and the well-known battle in the classical canon.
aptitude.course_name: The Classical Canon I: The Heritage of Antiquity

aptitude.question: Look at this graph showing the number of famous classical works from different ancient cultures included in the classical canon. Which culture contributed the most works?
tiny_learn: The classical canon includes key works from several ancient cultures, not just Greece and Rome.
Understanding the main contributors helps see how different cultures shaped later Western heritage.
Counting and comparing works from various cultures helps you grasp the scope of the canon.

graphData.title: Number of Key Classical Works by Ancient Culture

aptitude.hint: Look for the tallest bar representing the biggest number of works.
aptitude.course_name: The Classical Canon I: The Heritage of Antiquity

broad.question: You are preparing for the first seminar in Introduction to Communication Studies. Which step do you take first to engage effectively with the upcoming discussion on communication theories?
tiny_learn: Communication theories explain how people send, receive, and interpret messages in different contexts.
Start by reviewing lecture notes and assigned readings before joining group discussions to better understand the material.
This is what you will learn in the course "Introduction to Communication Studies" taught by prof. L. Morabito.

A.text: Dive into exploring how communication theories relate to societal impacts by attending a local community event.

B.text: Read assigned research articles carefully to understand the theoretical frameworks presented.

C.text: Create a visual mind map connecting different communication theories to clarify their interrelations.

aptitude.question: Sort these communication theories by their main focus: language, psychology, or sociology.
tiny_learn: Communication theories can focus on language, psychology, or sociology.
Interdisciplinary approaches help us understand communication better.
Classifying theories helps us see how different ideas explain communication.

items.text: Speech Act Theory, which studies how language performs actions.
Cognitive Dissonance Theory, about mental discomfort when beliefs conflict.
Social Identity Theory, explaining group membership and social behavior.
Conversation Analysis, focusing on how people use language in interaction.
Theory of Planned Behavior, which looks at attitudes and intentions.
Structuration Theory, about social structures shaping communication.

aptitude.hint: Think about whether the theory focuses on words, minds, or social groups.

aptitude.question: Complete the text by choosing the correct word for each blank.
tiny_learn: Communication studies combine ideas from psychology, sociology, and language.
Theories of communication focus on different parts like the message, the sender, or the social context.
Understanding communication helps us analyze real-life conversations and media messages.
aptitude.textWithBlanks: Communication Studies is an {{0}} field that mixes different scientific approaches. Some theories focus on the {{1}} used in messages, while others look at the {{2}} feelings and thoughts of the communicators.
aptitude.hint: Think about how Communication Studies use different sciences and what parts of communication they study.

aptitude.question: Look at this bar graph showing how often different communication theories were cited in recent studies. Which theory was cited the most?
tiny_learn: Communication studies use many theories from psychology, sociology, and language.
Theories are often tested by seeing how often they appear in research studies.
Counting citations helps us understand which theories are currently most influential.

graphData.title: Frequency of Citations of Communication Theories

aptitude.hint: Check which bar reaches the highest point on the graph.

aptitude.question: Classify these examples as related to either language acquisition or language disorders.
tiny_learn: Language acquisition is the process by which children learn sounds, words, and sentences.
Language disorders affect how people understand or produce language, like aphasia or developmental disorders.
Studying these differences helps linguists understand how language works in the brain and in communication.

items.text: A toddler starts saying their first words around 12 months.
An adult loses the ability to speak after a stroke.
A child learns to combine words into simple sentences by age 2.
A person has trouble understanding sentences due to aphasia.

aptitude.hint: Think about whether the example shows normal learning or a difficulty with language.

aptitude.question: Complete the text
tiny_learn: Phonetics studies the physical sounds of speech.
Morphology looks at how words are formed from smaller units.
Syntax explains how words combine to make sentences.
aptitude.textWithBlanks: In language acquisition, children first learn to produce basic {{0}} sounds before combining them into {{1}} and then into full {{2}}.
aptitude.hint: Think about the order in which children learn to speak: sounds, then small units, then full sentences.

aptitude.question: Look at this graph showing the average number of new words a child learns each month from age 12 to 24 months. Which month shows the fastest increase in word acquisition?
tiny_learn: Children learn words at different speeds during language development.
Linguists track word acquisition to understand how language skills grow.
Graphing word learning helps identify key stages in child language acquisition.

graphData.title: Average New Words Learned by Children (12-24 months)

aptitude.hint: Find where the graph line jumps the most steeply between two months.

F.text: Summarize key limit theorems into concise notes to review efficiently before the exam.

D.text: Discuss the assignment with classmates to understand different perspectives on the problem.

aptitude.question: Classify these expressions as either limits, derivatives, or integrals.
tiny_learn: A limit describes the value a function approaches as the input nears a point.
A derivative represents the rate at which a function changes at a given point.
An integral calculates the area under a curve within an interval.

items.text: d/dx (sin x)
∫₀¹ x² dx
lim (x→0) (sin x)/x
d/dx (e^x)
∫₁² (3x + 1) dx

aptitude.hint: Think about whether the expression studies behavior near a point, the slope of a curve, or the area under a curve.

aptitude.question: Complete the text by filling in the correct words about derivatives.
tiny_learn: The derivative of a function measures how fast the function's value changes.
The chain rule helps you find the derivative of a composition of functions.
The mean value theorem guarantees a point where the instantaneous rate of change equals the average rate.
aptitude.textWithBlanks: If a function f(x) is differentiable, then its {{0}} at a point x=a represents the slope of the {{1}} line to the curve at that point. To find the derivative of a function composed as g(f(x)), we use the {{2}} rule.
aptitude.hint: Think about how the slope of a curve at a point relates to the derivative and which rule applies to composite functions.

aptitude.question: Look at the graph showing the values of a function f(x) at different points. Which interval shows the function increasing the fastest?
tiny_learn: The derivative of a function tells us the rate at which it changes.
If the function goes up steeply, its derivative is large and positive.
Intervals where the function increases fastest have the steepest slope on the graph.

graphData.title: Function Values of f(x)

aptitude.hint: Check where the function values jump the most between two points.

aptitude.question: Arrange these limit expressions from smallest to largest value as x approaches 0:
tiny_learn: Limits help us understand the behavior of functions near a point.
The limit of sin(x)/x as x approaches 0 is 1.
Limits can be compared by approximating values close to the point.

value: lim (x→0) (1 - cos x) / x² < lim (x→0) (sin x) / x < lim (x→0) (eˣ - 1) / x
lim (x→0) (sin x) / x < lim (x→0) (1 - cos x) / x² < lim (x→0) (eˣ - 1) / x
lim (x→0) (eˣ - 1) / x < lim (x→0) (sin x) / x < lim (x→0) (1 - cos x) / x²
lim (x→0) (sin x) / x = lim (x→0) (eˣ - 1) / x = lim (x→0) (1 - cos x) / x²

aptitude.hint: Recall the known limits: sin x / x → 1, (1 - cos x) / x² → 1/2, and (eˣ - 1) / x → 1 as x→0.

tiny_learn: Algorithms are step-by-step instructions to solve problems.

Understanding both helps you turn ideas into working programs.

items.text: Repeat a set of instructions until a condition is met
Using 'for' to create a loop in code
Break down a big problem into smaller steps
Writing an 'if' statement to check a condition in code

aptitude.hint: Think about whether the item describes a general problem-solving idea or a specific way to write Python code.

aptitude.question: Complete the text
tiny_learn: Programming means giving a computer a clear set of instructions to solve a problem.
Python uses variables to store information that the program can use and change.
Loops allow a program to repeat actions until a condition is met.
aptitude.textWithBlanks: In Python, to repeat a task multiple times, you can use a {{0}}. A common type is the {{1}} loop, which repeats as long as a condition is true. Variables store values that can change during the loop. When the condition becomes false, the loop {{2}}.
aptitude.hint: Think about what repeats actions in a program until something changes.

broad.question: You have just started the course 'Academic Skills for Historians' and need to begin your first assignment by understanding what has already been written on your chosen historical topic. What is your first step?
tiny_learn: A status quaestionis is a clear description of what scholars have written about a topic and what questions remain unanswered.
Start by gathering and evaluating scientific literature and primary sources relevant to your topic.
In this course, 'Academic Skills for Historians' taught by prof. L. Morabito, you will learn how to write a well-structured status quaestionis and develop relevant research questions.

A.text: Visit the archives to handle original historical documents related to your topic.

B.text: Search and read recent academic articles and books about your topic online.

C.text: Create a visual mind map to organize different perspectives you find in the literature.

D.text: Discuss your initial findings with classmates to get their input and ideas.

E.text: Contact your professor or a librarian to ask for recommended resources and research tips.

F.text: Make a detailed checklist of all sources and annotations needed for your status quaestionis.

broad.question: You have just received the historiographical theme for your status quaestionis paper; what is your first step in approaching this topic?
tiny_learn: A status quaestionis summarizes existing research to identify debates and gaps.
Begin by systematically searching university library catalogs for scholarly literature.
This course 'Academic Skills for Historians' taught by prof. L. Morabito trains you in these essential research skills.

A.text: Start by brainstorming creative new ways to explore the topic and make the paper stand out.

B.text: Organize a study group to discuss and compare interpretations of the theme with peers.

C.text: Efficiently use the library’s online catalog to find relevant historical publications first.

D.text: Develop a detailed outline for your final paper before collecting sources.

E.text: Reach out to university faculty or experts to gain insight on current research challenges.

F.text: Visit local archives or historical sites to gather primary data for your literature review.

aptitude.question: Sort these sources into Primary or Secondary based on how historians use them.
tiny_learn: Primary sources are original materials from the time studied.
Secondary sources analyze or interpret primary sources or historical events.
Knowing the difference helps you build a strong research foundation.

items.text: A diary written by a soldier during World War II
A recent book analyzing the causes of World War II
A newspaper article published in 1945 reporting on the end of World War II
A historian’s review article summarizing various studies on the Cold War
Official census records from 1900

aptitude.hint: Think about whether the source was created during the historical event or later by researchers.

aptitude.question: Complete the text by choosing the correct words to explain key academic skills for historians.
tiny_learn: Primary sources are original materials from the past, while secondary sources analyze those materials.
Historians must critically assess the reliability and bias of sources they use.
Writing a historiographical essay involves summarizing different scholars' viewpoints on a historical topic.
aptitude.textWithBlanks: Historians start their research by examining {{0}} sources, which are original documents or artifacts from the period studied. Then, they consult {{1}} sources, which provide analysis and interpretation of those originals. To write a good historiographical essay, it is important to recognize different {{2}} among scholars and explain how these viewpoints contribute to the academic debate.
aptitude.hint: Think about the difference between original documents and later analyses, and what historians call different viewpoints.

aptitude.question: Look at the bar graph showing students' scores in three key skills from the Academic Skills for Historians course. Which skill did most students score highest in?

Evaluating sources carefully ensures that historians build strong, reliable arguments.

tiny_learn: Start your research by finding trustworthy books and articles in the university library catalog.
Summarize and paraphrase other authors' ideas carefully to avoid plagiarism.
Organize your literature review logically to show what is already known about your topic.

items.text: Searching the university library catalog for scientific publications
Evaluating the trustworthiness of a historical article
Summarizing key ideas from several historians in your own words
Correctly citing sources in footnotes and bibliography
Formulating a clear research question based on the literature read

aptitude.hint: Think about whether the task happens before or during writing your paper.

broad.question: You have just received the first literary text to analyze using the structuralist approach. What is your initial step to start your analysis?
tiny_learn: Structuralist analysis involves examining the underlying structures that shape a literary text.
Begin by identifying key literary techniques and patterns within the text systematically.
This is what you will learn in the course "Analysis of Literary Texts" taught by prof. S. Srinivasan.

A.text: Dive into the text and creatively rewrite a scene to explore its themes.

B.text: Read literary theory handbooks to understand how others interpret similar texts.

C.text: Outline the text's structure by marking patterns, motifs, and narrative techniques.

D.text: Discuss with classmates what the text might mean in today's society.

E.text: Reflect on how the text relates to your own life and feelings.

F.text: Investigate the historical and cultural context from which the text emerged.

In 'Creative Writing I' taught by prof. A. Kazemi, you will learn how to apply storytelling techniques to create engaging stories.

A.text: Go outside and observe people around you for inspiration to develop realistic characters.

E.text: Plan a schedule for weekly writing goals to steadily build your short story.

F.text: Create an outline breaking down scenes and plot points based on James Wood’s techniques.

items.text: Binary oppositions like 'good vs evil'
Author’s personal biography

Recurring symbols and motifs

broad.question: You are starting your first week in Ancient Philosophy and must prepare for the upcoming lecture on the origins of Greco-Roman and Sanskrit philosophical traditions. What is your first step?

A useful method is close reading, which means carefully analyzing primary texts for deeper understanding.
This course Ancient Philosophy, taught by prof. S. Srinivasan, will introduce you to these traditions and their connections.

aptitude.question: Sort these ancient philosophers into Greco-Roman or Sanskrit-Chinese traditions.
tiny_learn: Ancient philosophy includes thinkers from different cultural traditions.
Greco-Roman philosophy started around the 6th century BCE with figures like Socrates and Plato.
Sanskrit and Chinese traditions developed their own ideas about reality and knowledge around the same time.

items.text: Confucius, who explored ethics and social harmony.
Plato, who wrote about ideal forms and knowledge.
Laozi, founder of Daoism focusing on natural order.
Aristotle, who studied logic and categories of being.

aptitude.hint: Think about where each philosopher lived and the language of their original texts.

aptitude.question: Complete the text
tiny_learn: Ancient philosophy explores big questions about reality, knowledge, and how to live.
Different traditions like Greco-Roman, Chinese, and Sanskrit offer unique perspectives.
Philosophers use critical thinking to connect ideas across cultures and time.
aptitude.textWithBlanks: In Ancient Philosophy, the Greek thinker {{0}} is famous for his method of questioning to reach truth, called the {{1}} method. Meanwhile, in the Sanskrit tradition, the concept of {{2}} refers to the eternal, unchanging reality behind the world we see.
aptitude.hint: Think about the philosopher who used questioning to find truth and the Sanskrit term for ultimate reality.

aptitude.question: Look at this bar graph showing how many key philosophical works were produced by different ancient traditions between the 6th century BCE and the Global Middle Ages. Which tradition produced the most works?
tiny_learn: Ancient philosophy includes several major traditions like Greco-Roman, Sanskrit, and Chinese.
Philosophical works help us understand how ideas about reality and knowledge developed.
Comparing the number of writings helps us see the influence and activity of each tradition.

graphData.title: Number of Key Ancient Philosophical Works by Tradition

aptitude.hint: Look for the tallest bar representing the tradition with the most works.

aptitude.question: Sort these statements into "Knowledge" or "Belief" based on epistemological concepts.
tiny_learn: Knowledge is often defined as justified true belief.
Beliefs can be true or false, but knowledge requires justification.
Epistemology studies how we can know something, not just what we believe.

items.text: I am certain that water boils at 100°C at sea level because I have tested it.
I think it will rain tomorrow, but I’m not sure why.
My friend told me the Earth is flat, and I believe it without question.
I know that the Earth orbits the Sun because of scientific evidence.

aptitude.hint: Think about whether the statement involves justified evidence or just a personal guess.

aptitude.question: Complete the text
tiny_learn: Knowledge is often defined as justified true belief.
Epistemology studies how we can know things and what counts as good reasons.
Skepticism questions whether we can ever have certain knowledge.
aptitude.textWithBlanks: Epistemology asks: What is {{0}}? One common answer is that knowledge is a {{1}} true belief. But some philosophers worry that even if you believe something and have good reasons, you might still be wrong. This worry is called {{2}}.
aptitude.hint: Think about what philosophers say knowledge needs to include and what doubts challenge it.

aptitude.question: Look at this bar graph showing how many students chose different epistemological theories as their favorite. Which theory was the most popular?
tiny_learn: Epistemology studies how we know what we know and how we justify beliefs.
Philosophers debate different theories like Empiricism, Rationalism, and Skepticism to explain knowledge.
Understanding which theories people prefer can show how knowledge is valued or questioned.

graphData.title: Favorite Epistemological Theories Among Students

aptitude.hint: Look for the theory with the tallest bar representing the highest number of students.

aptitude.question: Sort these calculus concepts into 'Limits and Continuity' or 'Derivatives and Applications'.
tiny_learn: Limits help understand the behavior of functions near a point.
Derivatives measure how a function changes and find extreme values.
Continuity ensures a function has no sudden jumps or breaks.

items.text: Using l'Hôpital's rule to find a limit
Finding where a function has a local maximum
Checking if a function is continuous at a point
Applying the chain rule to differentiate a composite function
Using the squeeze theorem to evaluate a tricky limit

aptitude.hint: Think about whether the concept helps find how a function behaves near a point or how it changes.

aptitude.question: Complete the text
tiny_learn: A derivative shows how fast a function changes at any point.
Limits help us understand the behavior of functions near specific points.
The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus links derivatives and integrals.
aptitude.textWithBlanks: The derivative of a function at a point measures the {{0}} of the function there. When the derivative changes from positive to negative, the function has a {{1}} value at that point. To find this, we first calculate the {{2}} and then check where it equals zero.
aptitude.hint: Think about how the slope of a curve tells us about its behavior at a point.

aptitude.question: Look at the graph showing the derivative f'(x) of a function f. Which interval shows where the original function f(x) is increasing?
tiny_learn: The derivative f'(x) tells us where a function is increasing or decreasing.
If f'(x) > 0 on an interval, then f(x) is increasing there.
If f'(x) < 0 on an interval, then f(x) is decreasing there.

graphData.title: Derivative f'(x) over x

aptitude.hint: Where f'(x) is positive, f(x) is going up.

aptitude.question: Arrange these steps in the correct order to find the derivative of f(x) = (3x² + 2x)² using the chain rule.
tiny_learn: The chain rule helps find the derivative of a function composed inside another function.
First, identify the outer function and the inner function in the composition.
Multiply the derivative of the outer function by the derivative of the inner function.

sequence: Identify the outer function as g(u) = u² and inner function as u = 3x² + 2x
Find derivative of outer function: g'(u) = 2u
Find derivative of inner function: u' = 6x + 2

options.value: Identify outer function, find inner derivative, multiply, find outer derivative
Identify inner and outer functions, find outer derivative, find inner derivative, multiply both
Find inner derivative, identify functions, multiply, find outer derivative
Multiply derivatives, identify functions, find inner derivative, find outer derivative

aptitude.hint: First figure out the two functions, then find each derivative before multiplying.

aptitude.question: Sort these Business Analytics tasks into Descriptive, Predictive, or Prescriptive analytics.
tiny_learn: Descriptive analytics summarizes past data to understand what happened.
Predictive analytics uses data to forecast what might happen next.
Prescriptive analytics suggests actions to achieve desired outcomes.

items.text: Analyze last year’s sales data to find the best-selling product.
Use customer data to estimate who will buy a new product next month.
Recommend the optimal discount to increase sales next quarter.
Create a report showing monthly website visits for the past year.
Build a model to predict which customers might stop using the service.
Suggest the best inventory levels to minimize storage costs and stockouts.

aptitude.hint: Think about whether the task is about understanding past data, guessing the future, or deciding the best action.

aptitude.question: Complete the text
tiny_learn: Business Analytics uses data to help companies make better decisions.
Excel is a useful tool to organize and analyze business data.
Analytics includes descriptive (what happened), predictive (what might happen), and prescriptive (what to do) methods.
aptitude.textWithBlanks: Business Analytics helps companies understand their data by using methods like {{0}} analytics to describe past events, {{1}} analytics to predict future trends, and {{2}} analytics to suggest actions.
aptitude.hint: Think about the three main types of analytics that explain what happened, what might happen, and what to do next.

tiny_learn: Descriptive analytics summarizes past data to understand what happened.
Predictive analytics uses data to guess what might happen next.
Prescriptive analytics suggests the best actions to take based on data.

graphData.title: Accuracy of Analytics Methods in a Business Project

aptitude.hint: Look for the tallest bar, which shows the highest accuracy percentage.

aptitude.question: Classify these programming concepts as either 'Syntax' or 'Logic'.

items.text: Using an if statement to check if a number is positive
Ending a statement with a semicolon
Choosing the right operator to compare two values
Writing a function header with correct parameters

aptitude.hint: Think about whether the item is about how code is written or what the code does.

aptitude.question: Complete the text
tiny_learn: Programming uses data types like int and double to store values.
Control flow statements like if and loops decide how code runs.
Functions help organize code and can take inputs called parameters.
aptitude.textWithBlanks: In C++, a {{0}} is used to store whole numbers, while a {{1}} can store decimal numbers. To repeat a block of code multiple times, you use a {{2}} loop.
aptitude.hint: Think about which data types represent whole and decimal numbers, and which loop repeats code a fixed number of times.

aptitude.question: Looking at this bar graph of average test scores for different programming topics, which topic do students find the most challenging?
tiny_learn: Programming topics include basics like loops, functions, and error handling.
Higher test scores mean better understanding of the topic.
Identifying weaker topics helps you focus your study efforts.

graphData.title: Average Test Scores by Programming Topic

aptitude.hint: Look for the topic with the lowest average score.

aptitude.question: Arrange the code lines to print the sum of numbers from 1 to 5
tiny_learn: Loops let you repeat actions easily in code.
Variables can store changing values like sums or counters.
Indentation and order of lines matter to get the correct result.
aptitude.description: This code calculates and prints the sum of numbers from 1 to 5 using a loop.
aptitude.hint: Start by initializing the total before the loop begins.

aptitude.question: Classify each relation as Ordering, Equivalence, or Function.
tiny_learn: Ordering relations have properties like reflexivity, antisymmetry, and transitivity.
Equivalence relations are reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.
Functions assign exactly one output to each input.

items.text: The "less than or equal to" relation (≤) on numbers.
The relation "has the same remainder when divided by 3" on integers.
The relation that assigns to each student their unique student ID.
The relation "is a sibling of" among people.
The relation "is the parent of" among people.
The relation that assigns to each city its geographic coordinates.

aptitude.hint: Check if the relation groups elements, orders them, or pairs inputs to exactly one output.

aptitude.question: Complete the text
tiny_learn: A relation is symmetric if whenever (a, b) is in it, (b, a) is also in it.
An ordering relation must be reflexive, antisymmetric, and transitive.
Functions assign exactly one output to each input, and can be injective or surjective.
aptitude.textWithBlanks: In set theory, a relation R on set A is called {{0}} if for every element a in A, the pair (a, a) belongs to R. A relation is {{1}} if whenever (a, b) is in R, then (b, a) is also in R. Ordering relations are special because they are {{2}}, {{3}}, and {{4}}.
aptitude.hint: Think about how a relation behaves with pairs like (a, a) and pairs flipped like (b, a).

aptitude.question: Look at this bar graph showing the number of properties satisfied by three types of relations studied in Logic and Sets. Which relation type is symmetric but not necessarily antisymmetric?
tiny_learn: Equivalence relations are always symmetric, reflexive, and transitive.
Ordering relations are antisymmetric and transitive but not symmetric.
Functions can be seen as special relations with unique output for each input.

graphData.title: Properties of Relation Types

aptitude.hint: Think about which relation type must always be symmetric.

aptitude.question: Choose the correct set relation based on the Venn diagram shown: If Set A includes all even numbers and Set B includes all multiples of 4, which statement is true?
tiny_learn: A set is a collection of distinct elements.
A relation can show how elements from two sets relate to each other.
Ordering and equivalence relations have special properties like symmetry and transitivity.

options.value: Set B is a subset of Set A
Set A is a subset of Set B
Sets A and B are disjoint
Sets A and B have no intersection

aptitude.hint: Remember that all multiples of 4 are even numbers, but not all even numbers are multiples of 4.

broad.question: You have just started the "Economic Challenges" course and today's lecture covers the emergence of different economic paradigms in historical context. What is your first step to engage with the material?
tiny_learn: Economic paradigms are frameworks of ideas that economists use to explain how economies operate based on their social and political contexts.
A good method is to review lecture notes and read assigned texts to understand the development of these paradigms over time.
This is what you will learn in the course "Economic Challenges" taught by prof. K.N.M Mwandingi.

A.text: Discuss with classmates how historical events might have influenced economic theories in the class forum.

B.text: Analyze primary economic texts from different eras to identify changes in economic thinking.

C.text: Create a timeline chart mapping historical events alongside economic schools of thought.

D.text: Write a creative story imagining life during a key economic period and how ideas evolved.

E.text: Form a study group to debate the relevance of competing economic theories for current issues.

F.text: Spend time reflecting on how economic concepts affect your personal views on society.

broad.question: You are given a problem describing how market prices adjust to equilibrium. What is your first step to begin solving this mathematically?
tiny_learn: Mathematical models represent real-world situations with equations and variables.
Start by translating the problem statement into mathematical expressions or inequalities.
This course "Quantitative Research Methods I" taught by prof. S. Srinivasan helps you learn these modeling and problem-solving skills.

A.text: Draw a diagram or sketch to visualize the market equilibrium dynamics.

B.text: Search for existing mathematical formulas related to market equilibrium.

C.text: Create a written explanation of the problem to clarify your understanding.

D.text: Discuss the problem with classmates to explore different perspectives.

E.text: Identify key variables and translate the conditions into equations.

F.text: Set up a spreadsheet or software model to organize and analyze data.

R.question: You need to start your first assignment by approaching an economic challenge—what will you do first?
tiny_learn: Economic challenges arise from real-world market and government imperfections.
A good start is to research relevant economic theories linked to the problem.
In 'Economic Challenges' taught by prof. K.N.M Mwandingi, you will explore economic thought development and current issues.

A.text: Review historical economic theories to understand how past economists addressed similar challenges.

B.text: Investigate data and analyze trends to find evidence supporting different policy interventions.

C.text: Apply your knowledge by debating with peers about potential practical solutions to the economic problem.

broad.question: You receive your first weekly assignment involving proving a simple mathematical statement. What is your initial step to tackle this task?
tiny_learn: A mathematical proof is a logical argument that establishes the truth of a statement based on definitions and previously known results.
Start by carefully understanding the definitions and the statement you want to prove before choosing the proof strategy.
This is what you will learn in the course "Basic Concepts in Mathematics" taught by prof. A. Kazemi.

A.text: Draw a diagram or visualize examples to explore the statement intuitively.

B.text: Research similar proofs or theorems in textbooks or online resources to understand common methods.

C.text: Brainstorm creative ways or analogies that could help construct the proof.

D.text: Discuss the problem with peers to clarify your understanding and approach.

E.text: Motivate yourself by setting study goals and planning your weekly schedule to complete the assignments.

F.text: Carefully write down all given definitions and prerequisites related to the statement.

A.text: Brainstorm creative ways to visualize the function beyond standard graphs.

D.text: Discuss with classmates different approaches to estimating the function’s limit.

E.text: Use logical reasoning to identify dominant terms influencing the function's limit behavior.

F.text: Test how the function behaves using practical or spontaneous trial values close to the point.

aptitude.question: Sort these proof methods into direct or indirect proofs.
tiny_learn: Direct proofs show a statement is true by straightforward reasoning.
Indirect proofs include contrapositive and contradiction techniques.
Choosing the right proof method helps make arguments clear and convincing.

items.text: Proving "If n is even, then n^2 is even" by showing n=2k implies n^2=(2k)^2
Proving "If n^2 is even, then n is even" by assuming n is odd and reaching a contradiction
Proving "If a number is divisible by 4, then it is even" by writing a=4k and showing a=2(2k)
Proving "If a statement is false, then its negation is true" by proving the contrapositive

aptitude.hint: Direct proofs start with assumptions and move straight to the conclusion; indirect proofs use contradiction or contrapositive.

aptitude.question: Complete the text
tiny_learn: A direct proof shows a statement is true by starting from known facts.
A proof by contradiction assumes the opposite to find a conflict.
Induction proves statements true for all natural numbers step-by-step.
aptitude.textWithBlanks: To prove that a statement about all natural numbers is true, one common method is called {{0}}. First, we prove the statement for the smallest natural number. Then, we assume it is true for a number n and use this to prove it for {{1}}.
aptitude.hint: Think about the method that proves statements by checking the base case and a step from n to n + 1.

aptitude.question: Look at the graph of the number of elements in sets A, B, and their union A ∪ B. Which bar correctly represents the cardinality of A ∪ B?
tiny_learn: The cardinality of a set is the number of elements it contains.
The union of two sets contains all elements from both sets without duplicates.
To find the size of a union, add the sizes of the sets and subtract the size of their intersection.

graphData.title: Cardinalities of Sets

aptitude.hint: Remember that the union counts all unique elements from both sets.

aptitude.question:
Choose the correct next statement to complete this simple proof by contradiction:

Assume the statement "If n is an even number, then n² is even" is false. This means there is an even number n such that n² is not even. What is the next logical statement?
tiny_learn: A proof by contradiction starts by assuming the opposite of what you want to prove.
Even numbers can be written as 2 times some integer.
If n is even, then n² must also be even because it’s divisible by 4.

steps: There exists an even number n such that n² is not even.
Express n as 2k for some integer k.
Contradiction found, so the original statement is true.

options.value: Express n as an odd number 2k + 1.
Express n as 2k for some integer k.
State that n is not a number.

aptitude.hint: How do you represent an even number using a variable?

aptitude.question: Classify these calculus expressions as limits, derivatives, or integrals.
tiny_learn: Limits describe the behavior of a function near a point.
Derivatives represent how fast a function changes at a point.
Integrals calculate the total accumulation or area under a curve.

items.text: lim_{x→0} (sin x)/x
d/dx (e^x)
∫ x^2 dx
d/dx (ln x)
∫ cos x dx

aptitude.hint: Think about whether the expression describes approaching a value, rate of change, or area under a curve.

aptitude.question: Complete the text with the correct terms related to derivatives and limits.
tiny_learn: The derivative of a function measures how fast the function changes at a point.
Limits help us understand the behavior of functions near specific points or at infinity.
l'Hôpital's rule is useful to find limits when direct substitution gives indeterminate forms.
aptitude.textWithBlanks: To find the slope of the tangent line to the curve at a point, we calculate the {{0}} of the function. When evaluating a limit that results in 0/0 or ∞/∞, we can apply {{1}} rule to simplify the expression. The value the function approaches as x tends to a specific point is called the {{2}}.
aptitude.hint: Think about what calculus tools help analyze slopes and tricky limits.

aptitude.question: Sort these expressions by their limit as x approaches infinity, from smallest to largest:
tiny_learn: Limits describe the behavior of a function near a point or at infinity.
Dominant terms grow fastest and determine the limit at infinity.
Exponential functions grow faster than any polynomial function.
aptitude.hint: Think about which functions grow fastest as x becomes very large.

broad.question: You are starting your first seminar in 'Approaching Visual and Material Culture' and need to engage with the key concepts of visual representation. How do you begin?
tiny_learn: Visual literacy is the ability to interpret and make meaning from images and visual media.
A good method to start is to identify and define key terms and their cultural context.
This course teaches you about foundational concepts and multidisciplinary approaches, guided by prof. K.N.M Mwandingi.

A.text: Visit a museum to observe and reflect on the meaning and societal role of visual objects firsthand.

B.text: Research academic articles to understand how images function within cultural and social frameworks.

C.text: Sketch your own interpretation of an image to explore its medium and representation creatively.

D.text: Discuss with classmates their perspectives on how visual culture influences society in a group setting.

E.text: Present an argument in seminar on why interdisciplinary approaches yield stronger insights in visual culture.

F.text: Organize your notes methodically, categorizing key concepts and definitions before the seminar starts.

broad.question: You have just attended your first lecture on the Renaissance's impact on European culture. What is your initial step to engage with the material and prepare for upcoming assessments?
tiny_learn: European cultural history studies how historical events shape societal beliefs and artistic expression over time.
Start by reviewing lecture notes, reading primary sources, and discussing interpretations with classmates.
This is what you will learn in the course "European Cultural History" taught by prof. A. Kazemi.

A.text: Design a creative timeline illustrating the key cultural shifts during the Renaissance.

B.text: Research detailed historical facts about the Renaissance and take structured notes.

C.text: Discuss with peers how Renaissance ideas influence today's society.

D.text: Volunteer to lead the next group presentation on Enlightenment thought.

E.text: Reflect individually on how Renaissance art changed perspectives and write a personal essay.

F.text: Visit a museum or cultural site with Renaissance exhibits to experience the period firsthand.

R.question: You have been asked to analyze a famous artwork's symbolism and the artist's intended message. What is your first step?
tiny_learn: Representation is how meaning is conveyed through images and symbols in culture.
Start by closely examining the visual elements and researching their cultural context.
This course teaches you to understand visual literacy and the cultural functions of images with prof. K.N.M Mwandingi.

A.text: Research the historical and cultural background of the artwork to interpret its meaning.

B.text: Investigate the technical methods and materials used to create the artwork.

C.text: Analyze how the artwork communicates ideas and intentions through its imagery.

R.question: You have just started the course 'Approaching Visual and Material Culture' and need to decide how to begin exploring the key concept of visual culture. What is your first step?
tiny_learn: Visual culture studies how images and objects communicate meaning within societies.
A good method is to review foundational concepts and observe examples in context.
In this course taught by prof. K.N.M Mwandingi, you will learn to analyze images, media, and material culture from multiple perspectives.

A.text: Read introductory texts to understand core ideas about images and representation.

B.text: Collect and examine visual examples in your environment to observe their cultural significance.

C.text: Join a group discussion to share ideas and explore different disciplinary approaches.

R.question: You need to analyze a cultural image and decide how to start your research. What first step do you take?
tiny_learn: Visual culture studies how images and objects carry meaning in society.
Start by selecting a clear research question to focus your analysis.
In "Approaching Visual and Material Culture" taught by prof. K.N.M Mwandingi, you learn key concepts and research approaches.

A.text: Collect background literature to understand the cultural context of the image.

B.text: Directly observe and describe visual details of the image itself.

C.text: Plan how to systematically categorize the image within classification systems.

R.question: You are starting your first assignment in European Cultural History and need to decide how to approach it. Which first step do you take?
tiny_learn: Historical knowledge involves studying significant past events and their cultural impacts.
Effective study can begin by reviewing primary sources or summarizing core concepts from lectures.
In the course "European Cultural History" taught by prof. A. Kazemi, you will learn to analyze and recall European cultural developments from the medieval to modern times.

A.text: Start by outlining the key historical events covered in the lectures to frame your assignment.

B.text: Interpret original visual art and literature from the period as primary sources for your work.

C.text: Apply your own perspective to explain how cultural history influences modern society.

R.question: You have just started the European Cultural History course and need to decide how to prepare for the first class discussion on the Enlightenment period. What should you do first?
tiny_learn: Cultural history studies how cultural ideas and events shape societies over time.
Start by reviewing key lecture materials and primary source texts to build solid background knowledge.
In European Cultural History, taught by prof. A. Kazemi, you will explore major historical shifts through diverse sources and critical analysis.

A.text: Organize a study group to debate different interpretations of Enlightenment thinkers.

B.text: Read primary source texts and lecture notes carefully to understand the historical context.

C.text: Create a creative timeline poster highlighting key events in the Enlightenment era.

R.question: You are starting the course 'European Cultural History' and want to prepare effectively for your first presentation. Which approach do you choose first?
tiny_learn: Cultural history studies how societies' beliefs, politics, and arts change over time.
Review course readings and lecture notes carefully to gather relevant historical details.
In this course taught by prof. A. Kazemi, you will learn to analyze key European cultural shifts from the Middle Ages to today.

A.text: Research primary sources such as political treatises and visual art to support your presentation.

B.text: Engage in collaborative discussions with classmates to exchange ideas about historical themes.

C.text: Create an outline organizing your findings and main arguments clearly before drafting your slides.

A.question: You are starting the course 'Approaching Visual and Material Culture' and need to decide how to begin exploring key concepts related to images and their cultural meaning. Which first step do you choose?
tiny_learn: Visual culture studies how images and objects convey meaning within different societies and contexts.
Consider both the methods of analyzing images and how they relate to broader cultural and material settings.

C.text: Read the foundational text on image theory and its role in visual and material culture studies.

A.question: During your first seminar in Approaching Visual and Material Culture, you are asked to analyze an artwork using a specific approach. Which initial step will you take to best engage with the task?
tiny_learn: Visual culture studies how images and objects shape our perception in society.
Use interdisciplinary approaches to combine various perspectives for deeper analysis.
In this course, you will learn key concepts and methods from visual and material culture taught by prof. K.N.M Mwandingi.

A.text: Examine the material and sensory qualities of the artwork to understand its tangible impact.

B.text: Investigate how the artwork relates to social and cultural contexts influencing its meaning.

C.text: Classify the artwork using categories from different disciplines to explore combined perspectives.

A.question: You are starting your first assignment on the cultural consequences of industrialization in Europe. What is your first step to get a good start on the topic?
tiny_learn: Cultural history studies the ways societies express ideas, beliefs, and changes over time through art, literature, and social movements.

B.text: Collect and categorize primary historical documents and data about industrialization’s impact on European society.

C.text: Develop a presentation plan that demonstrates the societal shifts caused by industrialization using creative storytelling.

aptitude.question: Sort these examples into 'Visual Culture' or 'Material Culture' based on how they represent or communicate meaning.
tiny_learn: Visual culture includes images and visual media that communicate ideas.
Material culture consists of physical objects that carry cultural significance.
Understanding the difference helps analyze how meanings are created and shared.

items.text: A photograph published in a magazine
A traditional handmade pottery vase
A digital infographic explaining climate change
A historic wooden chair used in a cultural ceremony
A street mural depicting a political message
A designer handbag produced with specific cultural symbols

aptitude.hint: Think about whether the example is mainly an image or a physical object that holds meaning.

aptitude.question: Complete the text
tiny_learn: Images communicate meaning beyond words, influenced by their cultural context.
Mediums like photography or sculpture shape how we experience visual objects.
Visual culture studies consider multiple disciplines to understand how images work.
aptitude.textWithBlanks: In visual culture, an {{0}} is a representation created through a specific {{1}} such as painting or digital media. The way an image or object is understood depends on its {{2}}, including historical and social factors.
aptitude.hint: Think about how pictures are made and understood through their method and surroundings.

aptitude.question: Look at the bar graph showing the number of visual objects studied in different categories. Which category was studied the most?
tiny_learn: Visual culture studies how images and objects communicate meaning.
Different categories of objects help us explore how culture and society influence visual forms.
Counting and comparing studies of categories gives insight into focus areas in visual and material culture research.

graphData.title: Number of Visual Objects Studied by Category

aptitude.hint: Which bar reaches the highest value on the graph?

aptitude.question: Sort these European historical events into 'Religious Changes' or 'Artistic Movements'.
tiny_learn: European cultural history links events in religion and art to society's development.
Religious changes often influenced political and social structures in Europe.
Artistic movements reflect cultural shifts and ideas during different historical periods.

items.text: The Protestant Reformation
The Renaissance art flourishing
The Council of Trent reforms
The Baroque style development

aptitude.hint: Think about whether the event changed beliefs or created new styles of art.

aptitude.question: Complete the text
tiny_learn: The Renaissance was a time of renewed interest in art and science.
Religious changes deeply influenced European culture and politics.
Artistic styles often reflect the social and political ideas of their time.
aptitude.textWithBlanks: During the {{0}}, Europe experienced a revival of classical art and learning, which greatly influenced cultural and intellectual life. This period followed the {{1}} era, when religious authority was dominant. The changes in artistic expression during this time often reflected new ideas about {{2}} and humanity.
aptitude.hint: Think about the period known for rediscovering ancient knowledge and new ways of thinking.

aptitude.question: Looking at this graph of important European cultural movements by century, which century saw the greatest number of these movements?
tiny_learn: European cultural history studies key movements like the Renaissance and Enlightenment.
Cultural movements often reflect changes in art, science, and politics.
Understanding when movements happened helps explain how Europe changed over time.

graphData.title: Number of Key European Cultural Movements by Century

broad.question: You have just been assigned to prepare for your first seminar discussion on the ethical theories covered in Ethics (PPE). What is your first step to effectively engage with the topic?
tiny_learn: Ethical theories provide frameworks to evaluate what is right and wrong in various situations.
Start by reviewing key texts and summarizing main arguments to prepare for group discussions.
This is what you will learn in the course "Ethics (PPE)" taught by prof. A. Kazemi.

A.text: Gather practical examples of current moral issues to illustrate ethical theories in the seminar.

B.text: Read and take detailed notes on the assigned philosophical texts before the seminar.

C.text: Brainstorm creative ways to present ethical concepts visually during your seminar group.

D.text: Contact your seminar group members to discuss and organize a meeting for the discussion.

E.text: Debate your initial views on well-being theories with classmates to test your reasoning.

F.text: Create a detailed outline comparing the strengths and limitations of normative ethical theories.

broad.question: You have just been introduced to the mathematical optimization problems in Methods of PPE I. What is your first step in tackling a problem where you need to find the extreme values of a function?
tiny_learn: Mathematical optimization involves finding the best solution by maximizing or minimizing a function.
Start by differentiating the function and setting the derivative equal to zero to find critical points.
This is what you will learn in the course "Methods of PPE I" taught by prof. A. Kazemi.

A.text: Formulate a real-world scenario to apply the math problem and discuss it with classmates.

B.text: Start solving the function’s derivative to find critical points where the function's slope is zero.

C.text: Create a visual or artistic representation of the function’s shape to intuitively understand the problem.

D.text: Identify assumptions behind the function’s behavior and logically check if they hold true.

E.text: Discuss with your peers how this optimization relates to economic or political decision-making models.

F.text: Set up a systematic plan to research related game theory concepts that might influence the solution.

R.question: You are tackling your first seminar assignment on evaluating ethical theories. Which approach do you take first to start your analysis?

aptitude.question: Sort these ethical theories into 'Consequentialist' or 'Non-consequentialist'.
tiny_learn: Consequentialism judges actions by their outcomes or results.
Non-consequentialist theories focus on rules, duties, or character, not just outcomes.
Understanding these distinctions helps analyze moral problems clearly.

items.text: Utilitarianism (greatest happiness principle)
Kantian ethics (duty and universal moral laws)
Virtue ethics (focus on character traits)
Act consequentialism (evaluates each action by its result)

aptitude.hint: Think about whether the theory evaluates actions mainly by their results or by rules and character.

aptitude.question: Complete the text by filling in the blanks with the correct ethical theory names.
tiny_learn: Consequentialism judges actions by their outcomes or consequences.
Kantian ethics focuses on duties and moral rules regardless of outcomes.
Virtue ethics emphasizes character traits and moral virtues over rules or consequences.
aptitude.textWithBlanks: In ethics, {{0}} says the rightness of an action depends on its results, while {{1}} emphasizes acting according to moral duties. Meanwhile, {{2}} looks at the character of the person performing the action rather than just the action itself.
aptitude.hint: Think about which theory focuses on results, which on duties, and which on character.

aptitude.question: Look at the bar chart showing how many students preferred each ethical theory after a class discussion. Which ethical theory was chosen by the most students?
tiny_learn: Consequentialism focuses on the outcomes of actions to decide what is right.
Kantian ethics emphasizes duties and rules regardless of consequences.
Virtue ethics highlights the importance of character and moral habits.

graphData.title: Student Preferences for Ethical Theories

aptitude.hint: Look for the tallest bar representing the highest number of students.

aptitude.question: Sort these examples into 'Logic', 'Optimization', or 'Decision Theory' based on the Methods of PPE I course topics.
tiny_learn: Logic helps us structure arguments clearly using rules and symbols.
Optimization finds the best solution by maximizing or minimizing a function.
Decision theory studies how people make choices under uncertainty or interaction.

items.text: Using syllogisms to test if an argument is valid
Finding the maximum profit by adjusting price and production levels
Modeling how voters rank candidates in an election
Solving a system of equations to find equilibrium points
Using propositional logic to check the truth of combined statements
Analyzing strategies in a game where players choose simultaneously

aptitude.hint: Think about whether the example involves reasoning with rules, finding the best value, or making choices.

aptitude.question: Complete the text
tiny_learn: Optimization helps find the best solution under given conditions.
Logic uses formal rules to determine if statements are true or false.
Decision theory studies how individuals or groups make choices.
aptitude.textWithBlanks: In decision theory, the concept of {{0}} represents how much a person values different outcomes, helping to predict their choices. When optimizing a function of one variable, finding the {{1}} point means locating where the function reaches its highest or lowest value. In logic, a {{2}} is a structured argument that concludes something based on given premises.
aptitude.hint: Think about the terms from decision theory, optimization, and logic that describe value, best points, and structured arguments.

aptitude.question: Look at this graph showing three students' scores in a test on optimization and logic. Which student improved their score the most between Test 1 and Test 2?
tiny_learn: Optimization helps find best solutions under certain conditions.
Logic is about correct reasoning and valid arguments.
Tracking progress with data helps understand learning in PPE methods.

graphData.title: Test Scores on Optimization and Logic

aptitude.hint: Think about which student’s score increased the most from the first to the second test.
